unnormalised: I remember when online learning was just starting out in India. Back then, in 2015, my cousin, Priya Sharma, wanted to prepone her B.Com exams, but her college in Delhi didn't offer any extra classes. She was so stressed, and the only tuition centers she could find charged ₹500 per hour – way too much for our family then.
normalised: I remember when online learning was just starting out in India. Back then, in two thousand fifteen, my cousin, Priya Sharma, wanted to prepone her B-Com exams, but her college in Delhi didn't offer any extra classes. She was so stressed, and the only tuition centers she could find charged rupee five hundred per hour – way too much for our family then.

unnormalised: Then, someone told us about Coursera and Khan Academy. Priya was skeptical at first; she thought online classes wouldn't be as good as face-to-face learning. But she gave it a shot anyway. She enrolled in a finance course on Coursera for just $49, a fraction of what those tuition centers were asking.
normalised: Then, someone told us about Coursera and Khan Academy. Priya was skeptical at first; she thought online classes wouldn't be as good as face-to-face learning. But she gave it a shot anyway. She enrolled in a finance course on Coursera for just dollar forty nine, a fraction of what those tuition centers were asking.

unnormalised: What blew us away was how comprehensive the material was. Prof. Rajesh Kumar from IIM Bangalore was teaching one of the modules! Priya could watch the lectures at 2x speed to save time and even download them to watch offline since our internet connection was spotty back then. She’d often study from 10 PM to 2 AM, balancing it with her regular college work.
normalised: What blew us away was how comprehensive the material was. Professor Rajesh Kumar from I-I-M Bangalore was teaching one of the modules! Priya could watch the lectures at two times speed to save time and even download them to watch offline since our internet connection was spotty back then. She’d often study from ten P-M to two A-M, balancing it with her regular college work.

unnormalised: Thanks to those online courses, Priya aced her exams with 85%, a significant improvement from her previous scores. Seeing her success made me realize the potential of EdTech in India. Now, even my grandmother knows about BYJU's and Unacademy!
normalised: Thanks to those online courses, Priya aced her exams with eighty five percent, a significant improvement from her previous scores. Seeing her success made me realize the potential of EdTech in India. Now, even my grandmother knows about B-Y-J-U's and Unacademy!

unnormalised: These days, you see so many ads for EdTech platforms, offering everything from coding classes for kids to MBA prep courses. From my own experience and seeing how it helped Priya back in '15, I believe online learning is here to stay and will only become more integral to education in India. It bridges gaps and democratizes access in ways traditional education can't, all for a price like Rs. 15000 a year.
